thread.title: Global Scouse Day: 24 Liverpudlian phrases you really should know | London Evening Standard
thread.title_full: Global Scouse Day: 24 Liverpudlian phrases you really should know | London Evening Standard

author: Liz Connor
title: Global Scouse Day: 24 Liverpudlian phrases you really should know | London Evening Standard
text:
Global Scouse Day: 24 Liverpudlian phrases you really should know The bossest day of the year is here. Celebrate with these sound sayings Tuesday 28 February 2017 16:10 GMT Click to followES Lifestyle 
Liverpool has given us many things; the Beatles, the Albert Docks, Super Lamb Bananas and the tightest perms in the history of hairdressing. 
But it also has its very own language which, let’s face it, is hard to understand if you’ve never ventured further north than the M25. 
If you’ve payed a trip to Liverpool, you might have heard someone complaining abar their 'arl fella', sobbing over getting 'jibbed off' or exclaiming they’ve 'got a massive cob on'. 
As today, 28 February, marks Global Scouse Day - the day where the world stops and pays tribute to this great city - what better time to get to grips with the scouse language? 
Be confused no more and brush up on your banter with our guide. Sound 
Use: "How you doing?" "Yeah sound lad" Giving someone ‘down the banks’ 
Definition: to have a go at someone 
Use: “He didn’t come home until 3am, so I gave him down the banks” Arl arse 
Use: "Stop being an arl arse" Arl Fella 
Use: "I’m meeting my arl fella at the pub later" Wool 
Definition: someone who’s from the surrounding Merseyside areas, such as the Wirral or St Helens. 
Use: "He pretends he’s scouse but he’s actually a wool" G’wed 
Use: "Can I use your phone to send a text?" "G’wed girl" Lid
